results.title: Enough Rope: Can I Write the Ending?
results.creator_credit: Kerry Brewster, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Zapruder's Other Films
results.brief_description: What would you do if you thought you were about to die? This is an inspiring and moving story of three strong women, Annie Robinson, Nadeen Kovacic and Jasmyne Russell, each confronting life’s hardest journey, and how they’ve chosen to face their cancer and its ramifications. Presented by Andrew Denton, first broadcast on ABC Television on September 10, 2007.

results.title: After the Fires
results.brief_description:
After the worst fires in Canberra’s history in 2003, ABC TV gave four families small video cameras to record their lives after the fires.

Filmed by the families themselves, together with their friends, these short portraits of life in the months following this devastating event have now been edited into a moving one-hour documentary. Told from the families’ own perspective, the film captures milestones as they work towards regaining a semblance of normality in their lives.
Introduced by George Negus, this is a poignant story of paradise lost and paradise regained.

results.title: Adventure Island: The Diamond Tree
results.creator_credit: Godfrey Philipp, John Michael Howson and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Ho ho, ho ho, its far away we go, to a land that’s far across the sea. Hey hey, hey hey, for a little while we’ll stay, and be home in time for tea……..

The popular long-running children’s program ‘Adventure Island’ is set in the kingdom of Diddley-Dum-Diddley, and follows the continuing adventures of Liza, Clown, Mrs Flower Potts, Percy and Dodo Panda and their friends.

In this episode, a magical plant produces diamond flowers.

results.title: 7.30 Report: The Dismissal
results.brief_description:
On the eve of the thirtieth anniversary of the dismissal of the Whitlam government, a special edition of the ABC’s national nightly current affairs program, ‘7:30 Report’ takes an in-depth look at the events of 1975.

The program features interviews with both Gough Whitlam and Malcolm Fraser who comment on the events of 1975, discuss the possibility of 4 year fixed terms for both the House of Representatives and the Senate and reflect upon the politics of modern Australia, and upon each other.

Broadcast on 10th November, 2005.

results.title: Bellbird: Episode 205
results.creator_credit: Keith Wilkes, Oscar Whitbread and ABC
results.brief_description:
The ABC produced 1693 episodes of ‘Bellbird’ and the series ran for 10 years, until 1977. The series was a huge hit in rural and regional Australia because it dealt with the concerns of people living on the land and the dynamics of small country town life.
Episode 205 was broadcast on 1 January 1967.

results.title: Bilderbuch fur Ernst Will
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
The most complex and multi-layered of Callas’ CVI works, ‘Bilderbuch’ focuses on the geographic continent and turbulent political history of Europe. The primary image source of the work is a children’s wartime pictorial scrapbook (or ‘bilderbuch’). Callas has described ‘Bilderbuch fur Ernst Will’ as an ‘electronic rendering of a form of proto-televisual iconomania’, involving the collecting and collating of seemingly random images which, when seen together, reveal underlying narratives and belief systems.

Seen in this context, images from the child’s scrapbook come together to create a startling picture of wartime Europe and its legacy.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: The Esthetics of Disappearance
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
This work, which takes its title from Paul Virilio’s publication of the same name, explores notions of the cinematic in relation to recent global history, with particular focus on the role of the media in conveying information and events into the home via the medium of the television. Virilio’s thesis upon cinema and temporal experience proposed that ‘with the cinematic accelerator…the measure of the world becomes that of the vector of movement, of the means of locomotion that desynchronize time’. Notions of heightened speed and the distortion of perception are conveyed visually in the work by the rapidity of images and their intense colouration.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Double Trouble
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
One of the earliest works made by Callas using a Fairlight Computer Video Instrument (CVI) processor, a pioneering compositing and special effects system he utilised regularly from the mid 1980s to early 1990s. ‘Double Trouble’ is the first video made by Callas for a large exterior street screen form (in Tokyo). The image appears as though spliced into vertical halves, an array of imagery and characters appearing in double on either side of the division, and moving with alternating motion upwards and downwards. This two-frame animation technique creates two images from one checkerboard stencil which are then reversed, or asynchronously ‘mirrored’, producing an apt metaphor for cultural differences in ‘body language’ between East and West.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

The image appears as though spliced into vertical halves, an array of imagery and characters appearing in double on either side of the division, and moving with alternating motion upwards and downwards. results.title: The Genie from down under: larceny
results.creator_credit: Brendan Maher, Phil Jones, Patricia Edgar, British Broadcasting Corporation, ABC-TV (Australia) and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: Bruce helps Otto and Conrad get the opal because he thinks they will help him return to Australia. Instead, the von Meisters sell it for 25,000 pounds. It’s now up to the genies to sort the mess out.

results.title: The Genie from down under: customs
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Swan, Phil Jones, Patricia Edgar, British Broadcasting Corporation, ABC-TV (Australia) and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: Penelope, Lady Diana and Miss Mossop are arrested by a Customs Officer when they return to England with 20 million pounds provided by the genies. That exact amount has just gone missing from the Royal Mint.
